title: Edge Indicator
description: A set of Blueprints for indicating objects outside the player’s field of view
longDescription:
A set of Blueprints for indicating objects outside the player’s field of view. Indicators are located in the form of illuminated zones along the edges of the screen. Great for indicating enemies in Stealth or Horror games. Blueprints are very easy to use and configure.


Demonstration

VIDEO ON YOUTUBE


Documentation

GOOGLE DOCS


Possibilities

  • Indication of objects outside the player’s field of view along the edges of the screen.
  • The intensity of the indication depends on the distance and changes smoothly as the distance changes.
  • Blueprints are optimized for working with a large number of objects. BP_EdgeIndicatorComponent can sleep and wake up depending on distance, which significantly reduces the number of ticks.
  • BP_EdgeIndicatorComponents are automatically registered in BP_EdgeIndicator blueprint - this means that you do not have to worry about activating and deactivating them. Blueprints work without problems with World Partition.
  • You can easily customize the display style of the indicator, change its color, brightness, animation intensity, etc.


Blueprints are easy to use

  1. Add BP_EdgeIndicator to your level, set appropriate parameters;
  2. Add BP_EdgeIndicatorComponent to your Blueprints/Actors, move it to center it;
  3. Add MI_EdgeIndicatorPP Material to your Post Process volume.
  4. Play!
technicalDetails:
Parameters available for configuration

BP_EdgeIndicator allows you to configure the following parameters:

  • Minimum and Maximum distance. The indicator intensity is zero at Maximum distance and 1 at minimum distance.
  • Sleep Distance. The distance at which the components go to sleep mode.
  • The texture used to render the component.

BP_EdgeIndicatorComponent allows you to configure the following parameters:

  • Sleep Tick interval - minimum and maximum. When falling asleep, the component sets a random tick interval between the minimum and maximum. This ensures that multiple components are not ticking into the same frame.
  • Minimum and Maximum distance. Falling distance. These parameters can be overridden at runtime for each component.
